natural problem: Let $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}$ be orthogonal vectors.  If $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{a}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix},$ then find $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{b}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}.$
natural solution: Since $\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}$ is the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\mathbf{a},$ \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}\]is orthogonal to $\mathbf{a}.$  But since $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}$ are orthogonal, $\begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}$ is a scalar multiple of $\mathbf{b}.$

[asy] usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, O, P, Q, V; A = (3,2); B = (2,-3); O = (0,0); V = (0,13); P = (V + reflect(O,A)*(V))/2; draw(O--V,Arrow(6)); draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(P--V,Arrow(6));

draw((-1,0)--(7,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,15)); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}$", V, W); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}$", P, E); [/asy] Furthermore, \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}\]is a scalar multiple of $\mathbf{a},$ and therefore orthogonal to $\mathbf{b}.$  Hence, $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{b}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: "real*real" and proj :: "(real*real) \<Rightarrow> (real*real) \<Rightarrow> (real*real)"
assumes h0 : "a \<bullet> b = 0"
and h1 : "proj a (0,13) = (6,4)"
shows  "proj b (0,13) = (-6,9)"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}$ be orthogonal vectors.  If $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{a}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix},$ then find $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{b}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Since $\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}$ is the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\mathbf{a},$ \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}\]is orthogonal to $\mathbf{a}.$  But since $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}$ are orthogonal, $\begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}$ is a scalar multiple of $\mathbf{b}.$
 [asy] usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, O, P, Q, V; A = (3,2); B = (2,-3); O = (0,0); V = (0,13); P = (V + reflect(O,A)*(V))/2; draw(O--V,Arrow(6)); draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(P--V,Arrow(6));
 draw((-1,0)--(7,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,15)); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}$", V, W); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}$", P, E); [/asy] Furthermore, \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}\]is a scalar multiple of $\mathbf{a},$ and therefore orthogonal to $\mathbf{b}.$  Hence, $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{b}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: "real*real" and proj :: "(real*real) \<Rightarrow> (real*real) \<Rightarrow> (real*real)"
assumes h0 : "a \<bullet> b = 0"
and h1 : "proj a (0,13) = (6,4)"
shows  "proj b (0,13) = (-6,9)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given that vectors $a$ and $b$ are orthogonal (their dot product is zero), and that the projection of vector $a$ onto the vector $(0,13)$ results in the vector $(6,4)$, find the projection of vector $b$ onto the vector $(0,13)$. The final answer is $(-6,9)$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "a \<bullet> b = 0"
and h1 : "proj a (vector [0,13]) = vector [6,4]"
shows  "proj b (vector [0,13]) = vector [-6,9]" (* Projection of vector [0,13] onto b is [-6,9] *)
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}$ be orthogonal vectors.  If $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{a}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix},$ then find $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{b}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Since $\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}$ is the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\mathbf{a},$ \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}\]is orthogonal to $\mathbf{a}.$  But since $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}$ are orthogonal, $\begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}$ is a scalar multiple of $\mathbf{b}.$
 [asy] usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, O, P, Q, V; A = (3,2); B = (2,-3); O = (0,0); V = (0,13); P = (V + reflect(O,A)*(V))/2; draw(O--V,Arrow(6)); draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(P--V,Arrow(6));
 draw((-1,0)--(7,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,15)); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}$", V, W); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}$", P, E); [/asy] Furthermore, \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}\]is a scalar multiple of $\mathbf{a},$ and therefore orthogonal to $\mathbf{b}.$  Hence, $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{b}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "a \<bullet> b = 0"
and h1 : "proj a (vector [0,13]) = vector [6,4]"
shows  "proj b (vector [0,13]) = vector [-6,9]" (* Projection of vector [0,13] onto b is [-6,9] *)
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given two two-dimensional vectors $a$ and $b$ that are orthogonal to each other (i.e., their dot product equals zero), if the projection of the vector [0,13] onto $a$ is the vector [6,4], then find the projection of the vector [0,13] onto $b$. The final answer is the vector [-6,9].

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: "real * real"
and proj_a :: "real * real \<Rightarrow> real * real"
and proj_b :: "real * real \<Rightarrow> real * real"
assumes h0 : "orthogonal a b"
and h1 : "\<forall>v. proj_a v = (dotprod v a / dotprod a a) *\<^sub>R a"
and h2 : "proj_a (0, 13) = (6, 4)"
shows  "proj_b (0, 13) = (-6, 9)"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}$ be orthogonal vectors.  If $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{a}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix},$ then find $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{b}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Since $\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}$ is the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\mathbf{a},$ \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}\]is orthogonal to $\mathbf{a}.$  But since $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}$ are orthogonal, $\begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}$ is a scalar multiple of $\mathbf{b}.$
 [asy] usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, O, P, Q, V; A = (3,2); B = (2,-3); O = (0,0); V = (0,13); P = (V + reflect(O,A)*(V))/2; draw(O--V,Arrow(6)); draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(P--V,Arrow(6));
 draw((-1,0)--(7,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,15)); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}$", V, W); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}$", P, E); [/asy] Furthermore, \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}\]is a scalar multiple of $\mathbf{a},$ and therefore orthogonal to $\mathbf{b}.$  Hence, $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{b}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: "real * real"
and proj_a :: "real * real \<Rightarrow> real * real"
and proj_b :: "real * real \<Rightarrow> real * real"
assumes h0 : "orthogonal a b"
and h1 : "\<forall>v. proj_a v = (dotprod v a / dotprod a a) *\<^sub>R a"
and h2 : "proj_a (0, 13) = (6, 4)"
shows  "proj_b (0, 13) = (-6, 9)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given two orthogonal vectors a and b, if the projection of the vector (0,13) onto a is (6,4) using the formula for projection as $\frac{\text{dot product of v and a}}{\text{dot product of a and a}}$ times vector a, find the projection of the vector (0,13) onto b. The final answer is (-6,9).

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"

a_3.formal solution:

theorem
fixes a b :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "orthogonal a b"
and h1 : "proj a (0, 13) = (6, 4)"
shows  "proj b (0, 13) = (-6, 9)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Assume that vectors a and b are orthogonal. If the projection of a onto (0, 13) is (6, 4), find the projection of b onto (0, 13). The final answer is (-6, 9).

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: "real^2" and proj_a proj_b :: "real^2 \<Rightarrow> real^2"
assumes h0 : "a \<bullet> b = 0"
and h1 : "proj_a (vector [0, 13]) = vector [6, 4]"
and h2 : "\<forall> v. proj_a v = (v \<bullet> a / (a \<bullet> a)) *\<^sub>R a"
and h3 : "\<forall> v. proj_b v = (v \<bullet> b / (b \<bullet> b)) *\<^sub>R b"
shows  "proj_b (vector [0, 13]) = vector [-6, 9]"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}$ be orthogonal vectors.  If $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{a}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix},$ then find $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{b}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Since $\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}$ is the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\mathbf{a},$ \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}\]is orthogonal to $\mathbf{a}.$  But since $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}$ are orthogonal, $\begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}$ is a scalar multiple of $\mathbf{b}.$
 [asy] usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, O, P, Q, V; A = (3,2); B = (2,-3); O = (0,0); V = (0,13); P = (V + reflect(O,A)*(V))/2; draw(O--V,Arrow(6)); draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(P--V,Arrow(6));
 draw((-1,0)--(7,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,15)); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}$", V, W); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}$", P, E); [/asy] Furthermore, \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}\]is a scalar multiple of $\mathbf{a},$ and therefore orthogonal to $\mathbf{b}.$  Hence, $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{b}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: "real^2" and proj_a proj_b :: "real^2 \<Rightarrow> real^2"
assumes h0 : "a \<bullet> b = 0"
and h1 : "proj_a (vector [0, 13]) = vector [6, 4]"
and h2 : "\<forall> v. proj_a v = (v \<bullet> a / (a \<bullet> a)) *\<^sub>R a"
and h3 : "\<forall> v. proj_b v = (v \<bullet> b / (b \<bullet> b)) *\<^sub>R b"
shows  "proj_b (vector [0, 13]) = vector [-6, 9]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given two perpendicular vectors $a$ and $b$, and the projections of any vector $v$ onto $a$ and $b$ are defined by $\frac{v \cdot a}{a \cdot a}a$ and $\frac{v \cdot b}{b \cdot b}b$ respectively. If the projection of the vector [0, 13] onto $a$ is [6, 4], what is the projection of the vector [0, 13] onto $b$? The final answer is [-6, 9].

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: "real*real" and proj_a proj_b :: "real*real \<Rightarrow> real*real"
assumes h0 : "a \<bullet> b = 0"
and h1 : "proj_a (0, 13) = (6, 4)"
and h2 : "\<forall> v. proj_b v = v - proj_a v"
shows  "proj_b (0, 13) = (-6, 9)"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}$ be orthogonal vectors.  If $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{a}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix},$ then find $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{b}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Since $\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}$ is the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\mathbf{a},$ \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}\]is orthogonal to $\mathbf{a}.$  But since $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}$ are orthogonal, $\begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}$ is a scalar multiple of $\mathbf{b}.$
 [asy] usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, O, P, Q, V; A = (3,2); B = (2,-3); O = (0,0); V = (0,13); P = (V + reflect(O,A)*(V))/2; draw(O--V,Arrow(6)); draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(P--V,Arrow(6));
 draw((-1,0)--(7,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,15)); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}$", V, W); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}$", P, E); [/asy] Furthermore, \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}\]is a scalar multiple of $\mathbf{a},$ and therefore orthogonal to $\mathbf{b}.$  Hence, $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{b}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: "real*real" and proj_a proj_b :: "real*real \<Rightarrow> real*real"
assumes h0 : "a \<bullet> b = 0"
and h1 : "proj_a (0, 13) = (6, 4)"
and h2 : "\<forall> v. proj_b v = v - proj_a v"
shows  "proj_b (0, 13) = (-6, 9)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given that vectors $a$ and $b$ are orthogonal (their dot product is zero), vector $a$ is projected onto $(0, 13)$ resulting in $(6, 4)$. If vector $b$ is the difference between any vector $v$ and its projection on $a$, find the projection of $b$ on $(0, 13)$. The final answer is $(-6, 9)$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
and v w :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. a x y = 0"
and h1 : "v 0 = 13"
and h2 : "proj a v = (\<lambda>x. if x = 0 then 6 else 4)"
shows  "proj b v = (\<lambda>x. if x = 0 then -6 else 9)" (* proj_b (0,13) = (-6,9) *)
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}$ be orthogonal vectors.  If $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{a}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix},$ then find $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{b}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Since $\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}$ is the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\mathbf{a},$ \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}\]is orthogonal to $\mathbf{a}.$  But since $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}$ are orthogonal, $\begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}$ is a scalar multiple of $\mathbf{b}.$
 [asy] usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, O, P, Q, V; A = (3,2); B = (2,-3); O = (0,0); V = (0,13); P = (V + reflect(O,A)*(V))/2; draw(O--V,Arrow(6)); draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(P--V,Arrow(6));

 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
and v w :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x y. a x y = 0"
and h1 : "v 0 = 13"
and h2 : "proj a v = (\<lambda>x. if x = 0 then 6 else 4)"
shows  "proj b v = (\<lambda>x. if x = 0 then -6 else 9)" (* proj_b (0,13) = (-6,9) *)
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given the function $a(x, y) = 0$ and the function $v(x) = 13$ when $x = 0$, and given that the projection of $v$ onto $a$, $proj_a(v)$, is equal to $6$ when $x = 0$ and equal to $4$ otherwise. Find the function $b$ such that the projection of $v$ onto $b$, $proj_b(v)$, is equal to $-6$ when $x = 0$ and equal to $9$ otherwise.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "orthogonal a b"
and h1 : "projection a (vector [0, 13]) = vector [6, 4]"
shows  "projection b (vector [0, 13]) = vector [-6, 9]"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}$ be orthogonal vectors.  If $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{a}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix},$ then find $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{b}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}

 Since $\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}$ is the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\mathbf{a},$ \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}\]is orthogonal to $\mathbf{a}.$  But since $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}$ are orthogonal, $\begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}$ is a scalar multiple of $\mathbf{b}.$

 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "orthogonal a b"
and h1 : "projection a (vector [0, 13]) = vector [6, 4]"
shows  "projection b (vector [0, 13]) = vector [-6, 9]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given two orthogonal vectors $a$ and $b$, if the projection of vector $a$ onto the vector $[0, 13]$ is $[6, 4]$, find the projection of vector $b$ onto the vector $[0, 13]$. The final answer is $[-6, 9]$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "inner a b = 0"
and h1 : "inner (a 0 13) = (a 6 4)"
shows  "inner (b 0 13) = (b -6 9)"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}$ be orthogonal vectors.  If $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{a}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix},$ then find $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{b}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}

 draw((-1,0)--(7,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,15)); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}$", V, W); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}$", P, E); [/asy] Furthermore, \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}\]is a scalar multiple of $\mathbf{a},$ and therefore orthogonal to $\mathbf{b}.$  Hence, $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{b}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "inner a b = 0"
and h1 : "inner (a 0 13) = (a 6 4)"
shows  "inner (b 0 13) = (b -6 9)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given two real-valued functions a and b such that their inner product is zero and that the inner product of a(0,13) is equal to a(6,4), show that the inner product of b(0,13) is equal to b(-6,9).

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: "real^2" and proj_a proj_b :: "real^2 \<Rightarrow> real^2"
assumes h0 : "inner a b = 0"
and h1 : "proj_a (vector [0, 13]) = vector [6, 4]"
and h2 : "\<forall> v. proj_a v = (inner v a / inner a a) *\<^sub>R a"
and h3 : "\<forall> v. proj_b v = (inner v b / inner b b) *\<^sub>R b"
shows  "proj_b (vector [0, 13]) = vector [-6, 9]"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}$ be orthogonal vectors.  If $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{a}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix},$ then find $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{b}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Since $\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}$ is the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\mathbf{a},$ \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}\]is orthogonal to $\mathbf{a}.$  But since $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}$ are orthogonal, $\begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}$ is a scalar multiple of $\mathbf{b}.$
 [asy] usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(0.4 cm); pair A, B, O, P, Q, V; A = (3,2); B = (2,-3); O = (0,0); V = (0,13); P = (V + reflect(O,A)*(V))/2; draw(O--V,Arrow(6)); draw(O--P,Arrow(6)); draw(P--V,Arrow(6));
 draw((-1,0)--(7,0)); draw((0,-1)--(0,15)); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix}$", V, W); label("$\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}$", P, E); [/asy] Furthermore, \[\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 4 \end{pmatrix}\]is a scalar multiple of $\mathbf{a},$ and therefore orthogonal to $\mathbf{b}.$  Hence, $\operatorname{proj}_{\mathbf{b}} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 13 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -6 \\ 9 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: "real^2" and proj_a proj_b :: "real^2 \<Rightarrow> real^2"
assumes h0 : "inner a b = 0"
and h1 : "proj_a (vector [0, 13]) = vector [6, 4]"
and h2 : "\<forall> v. proj_a v = (inner v a / inner a a) *\<^sub>R a"
and h3 : "\<forall> v. proj_b v = (inner v b / inner b b) *\<^sub>R b"
shows  "proj_b (vector [0, 13]) = vector [-6, 9]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given that vectors a and b are orthogonal (their inner product is zero), find the projection of the vector [0, 13] onto vector b, if it is known that the projection of [0, 13] onto vector a gives [6, 4]. The final answer is [-6, 9].
